alert.note: Alert for Escambia Coastal; Escambia Inland; Santa Rosa Coastal; Santa Rosa Inland (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued December 20 at 7:58AM EST by NWS Mobile
info.description: ...A SURGE OF ARCTIC AIR WILL BRING BITTERLY COLD TEMPERATURES TO THE REGION LATE THIS WEEK AND INTO THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY WEEKEND... An arctic cold front is forecast to sweep across southeast Mississippi, southwest and south central Alabama, and the western Florida panhandle late Thursday night into early Friday morning. Dangerously cold temperatures are expected to settle into our area following the passage of the cold front late this week and into the upcoming Christmas holiday weekend. Low temperatures early Friday morning will likely fall into the teens to near 20 degrees across southeast Mississippi and much of interior southwest Alabama along and northwest of the Interstate 65 corridor, with lows in the mid 20s to lower 30s across the remainder of south central Alabama and the western Florida panhandle. High temperatures on Friday are only expected to reach into the mid 20s to lower 30s across much of southeast Mississippi and interior southwest Alabama. The coldest temperatures are expected on Friday night with temperatures expected to fall into the teens over most areas along and north of Interstate 10, with freezing temperatures in the 20s expected all the way to the immediate coast and beaches. Highs on Christmas Eve are currently forecast to only reach into the 30s over most of our region, while lows early Christmas morning once again fall into the teens and 20s. Highs on Christmas Day are expected to remain cold in the 30s to lower 40s across the area. Blustery northwesterly winds are expected to bring dangerously low wind chills in the single digits and teens across our region Friday morning through Christmas morning, with a few spots over interior areas potentially below zero. Widespread Hard Freeze Watches and Wind Chill Watches for this outbreak of arctic air will likely become necessary across much of our region and may be issued later today or tonight. Residents across the area should continue to monitor the forecast closely this week. Prepare now for bitterly cold temperatures. Take steps to protect water pipes and ensure people, animals, and sensitive vegetation will have ready access to warmth late this week and this holiday weekend.
